HEADLINE: Nassau Aid Went to Campaign Donors

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT and SHELLY FEUER DOMASH

 BODY:
EVERY company that received material assistance from the Nassau County Industrial Development Agency in 2003 was a contributor to the campaign treasuries of the county executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, or David Mejias, who was the treasurer of the agency before becoming a county legislator last year, a review of official filings shows.
 The records also show that the agency employed a variety of individuals and companies with political connections to Mr. Suozzi, a Democrat who campaigned for the county executive's job in 2001 with a pledge to ''dismantle the culture of machine politics'' that flourished during decades of Republican control and put government on a merit system.
 For most of Mr. Suozzi's first two years in office, the Nassau I.D.A., created in 1975 and empowered to grant low-cost loans and tax breaks as incentives to lure businesses and promote job growth, was under the purview of Peter T. Sylver. Mr. Sylver was Mr. Suozzi's deputy county executive for economic development but resigned last November after being accused of corruption, nepotism and sexual harassment. 
 Last month Mr. Sylver pleaded guilty to charges of official misconduct for billing personal expenses to the county, sexual abuse of an employee in his county car and forcing an assistant into political activity. He paid $5,700 in restitution and was sentenced to three years of probation. In addition the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development is demanding that the county refund nearly $1 million in federal aid that was misspent by other agencies under Mr. Sylver's control. 
 As county executive, Mr. Suozzi appoints the Industrial Development Agency's six-member board, which in turn makes all hires. 
 Under Mr. Suozzi and Mr. Sylver, several prominent Democrats have been either running the agency, working for it or winning benefits from it. They include present or former public officials, party officers and candidates closely tied to Mr. Suozzi's political operations.
 The agency's year-end reports for 2003, the first full year that the Democrats were in control, show that it approved six projects involving for-profit companies. The six projects, with a total estimated value of $177 million, were granted various property tax, sales tax and mortgage tax reductions and approvals for low-cost loans. 
 Collectively, the benefits are worth tens of millions of dollars. The precise amount is undocumented because the biggest factor is the low-interest financing, and there is no way to know the exact savings from what conventional loans might have cost for the various deals.
 All six companies that won benefits from Mr. Suozzi's appointees gave campaign contributions to Mr. Suozzi or Mr. Mejias, either directly or through company officers or allied firms. Those donations amounted to $67,750. 
 In addition, lawyers and other consultants hired by the agency -- under contracts often awarded without competitive bidding -- also contributed to the Democrats, according to official records. Their donations added up to an additional $87,550, for a grand total of $155,000. The contributions were made at various times, before and after Mr. Suozzi's election in 2001.
 Mr. Suozzi, who is fast gaining a reputation as a prodigious fund-raiser for himself and even presidential candidates, was the prime beneficiary of the donations. His campaign fund received $145,600 from the businesses and consultants who dealt with the agency, often in $5,000 and $10,000 chunks. Mr. Mejias, who served as the agency's unpaid treasurer last year, received $9,700 in contributions from agency-related donors for his successful County Legislature campaign.
 Joseph Gioino, executive director of the Industrial Development Agency, denied that politics and donations influence its actions. ''One has nothing to do with the other,'' he said. ''I'm sure these same applicants have given to both sides. Developers are not ideological. They're equal-opportunity givers. I know for a fact some have given to Pataki.''
 Mr. Suozzi does not get involved in agency decisions, Mr. Gioino said. ''Any company that meets the necessary qualification standards receives I.D.A. financing,'' he said. ''Companies do not need a connection, and the more companies the I.D.A. is able to assist, the better for everyone.''
 But Nassau Republican officials accuse the administration of politicizing the agency and milking the program for donations that give at least the appearance of favoritism and conflict of interest.
 The County Legislature's Republican minority leader, Peter J. Schmitt, accused Mr. Suozzi of exploiting the agency to help his ''cronies.'' A Republican spokesman, Edward Ward, called the agency ''completely patronage-ridden'' and said, ''Tom Suozzi has used the I.D.A. to enrich his campaign war chest for future political office.''
 Appointing political allies to public office is an old tradition, and campaign contributions from people doing business with government are also a fixture of local, state and national politics. While such donations do not by themselves violate bribery or extortion laws, critics say that such actions can give the impression that contributors are currying favor or that officials are pressuring them for money or rewarding donors with public benefits.
 ''The issue is conflict of interest,'' said Tara Radin, who teaches business ethics at Hofstra University. ''Whether they want to admit it nor not, that is what is going on.'' 
 A Democratic county legislator, Lisanne G. Altmann, also voiced concern about the image that businesses ''have to pay to play.'' She has been drafting laws to curb such donations.

Tax Breaks Worth Millions
 Like similar local agencies elsewhere, Nassau's Industrial Development Agency uses various financial rewards to entice business to move or expand there. The agency can reduce or waive property taxes, mortgage recording taxes and sales taxes for construction material, furnishings and equipment. Even more important, the agency also authorizes applicants to get loans whose interest is fully or partly tax-exempt, which lowers the effective rate by 1 to 1.5 percentage points, Mr. Gioino said. Those reductions can save millions of dollars over the life of loans that last up to 30 years.
 Over all, the total value of bonds approved under Mr. Suozzi has grown, as measured by the fees that applicants paid -- about 0.6 percent of the value of the bond. Under the administration of his Republican predecessor, Thomas S. Gulotta, the total fees averaged $300,000 a year. In 2002 they reached $537,226, and last year they totaled $1.2 million. 
 Several nonprofit organizations received benefits from the county agency, but they are generally barred, by law or policy, from making political contributions. Six for-profit projects were assisted by the I.D.A. in 2003, and campaign donations to Mr. Suozzi or Mr. Mejias were made in all six cases, either by the companies themselves, their principals or their subsidiaries. They include:
 $(6$)Tweezerman, a Port Washington-based manufacturer of personal grooming tools that got a $4 million bond and $357,752 in tax reductions from the agency to renovate a 90,000-square-foot building for an audio and video product distribution center. The company's founder, Dal LaMagna, ran twice as a Democratic candidate for Congress, unsuccessfully. He said his two campaign donations to Mr. Suozzi, totaling $10,000, were unrelated to the project, which would add 15 jobs and avert a possible move to Houston. ''I have personally been a big supporter of Suozzi from the first day I met him,'' Mr. LaMagna said.
 $(6$)Forest City Daly, a Manhattan real estate development company that was the beneficiary of the agency's biggest bond issue in at a least a dozen years: $65 million for a 165-unit residence for the elderly on seven acres in Roslyn, with construction due to start in 2007. Besides the interest savings on the loan, the tax reduction is $86,081. The firm and its president, Michael D. Daly, gave a total of $13,000 in campaign contributions, $11,000 to Mr. Suozzi and $2,000 to Mr. Mejias. Mr. Daly did not respond to requests for comment.
 $(6$)EBS North Hills, a development company owned by Steve Krieger and Jan Burman. It received a $32 million bond for the construction of an assisted-living center on four acres in North Hills. In addition to the low-cost loan, the upfront tax abatements totaled $660,512. Some phases of the project were approved in 2002 and 2004, as well as 2003. Through their various companies, Mr. Kreiger and Mr. Burman made seven donations to Mr. Suozzi totaling $17,500. Mr. Burman said that they have supported numerous candidates and that ''our request for I.D.A. financing was part of a transparent and open process that violated neither the spirit nor the letter of any law.''
 $(6$)MONY at Lake Success, owned by Frank Lalezarian, which was authorized for a $17.5 million bond to build commercial office space at 1999 Marcus Avenue. Besides the low-cost financing, his initial tax abatements are $572,896. Through his MONY, Old Mill Partners, Oxford Construction and Split Rock Construction companies, Mr. Lalezarian made several donations totaling $22,000 to Mr. Suozzi's campaign. He did not return calls seeking his comment.
 $(6$)Alan Mindel, a developer whose plan for an 84-unit motel on about an acre in Plainview benefited from a $5 million bond issued by the agency. Besides the low-cost financing, the project won $407,207 in tax reductions. Mr. Mindel, who also owns the Inn at Great Neck, donated $5,000 to Mr. Suozzi. He did not return calls seeking comment.
 $(6$)Keyspan, an energy company that was approved for a $53 million bond for three buildings and two gas-fired electrical generators on 2.9 acres in Glenwood Landing. Though the project will not create jobs beyond the installation, Mr. Gioino said that holding electricity costs down with efficient new generators will help businesses throughout the county. Keyspan gave a $250 check to Mr. Mejias's campaign, but he returned it.
 Mr. Suozzi defended the projects, saying that even his critics have not found anything wrong with them. ''They obviously can't comment on the merits of any projects of the I.D.A.,'' he said, ''so they have these bogus claims that are really a stretch,'' about the fund-raising.
 ''No contribution is going to influence the policy of this administration or my actions personally or any of my staff members,'' Mr. Suozzi said. The donations ''were both legal and ethical and not that significant'' considering the $6 million total he has raised, he said. He also said he didn't recognize some of the donors, like Mr. Daly. ''I don't even know who the guy is,'' he said.

Allies at the Agency
 Under Mr. Suozzi, the Industrial Development Agency has been a magnet for prominent Democrats and their businesses. They include:
 $(6$)Lewis Yevoli, the agency's chairman last year. Mr. Yevoli, formerly a Democratic assemblyman, Oyster Bay town supervisor and member of the old County Board of Supervisors, is a longtime political ally of Mr. Suozzi and endorsed Mr. Suozzi's underdog bid for county executive. Mr. Yevoli left the agency to become chairman of the county Planning Commission, a promotion by Mr. Suozzi.
 $(6$)Howard Fensterman, the agency's current chairman and managing partner of the Abrams, Fensterman, Fensterman, Flowers, Greenberg & Eisman law firm in Lake Success. The firm's Web site says that he is Senator Charles Schumer's campaign finance cochairman on Long Island and vice chairman of the Nassau Democrats' screening panel for judicial candidates. ''His involvement in the political process has resulted in Mr. Fensterman's having forged special relationships with several U.S. Senators, congresspersons, state senators and assembly persons,'' the Web site says.
 $(6$)Mr. Gioino, the agency's $98,800-a-year executive director, who simultaneously served as a Democratic city councilman in Glen Cove, where Mr. Suozzi was mayor and remains the paramount leader. Mr. Gioino's bid for re-election last fall ended in a tied vote with a Republican, Grady Farnan. The seat was declared vacant, and both men are running again this year to fill it.
 $(6$)Mr. Mejias, who ran as a Suozzi protege for the County Legislature last year while serving as the agency's unpaid treasurer and as a board member. His victory preserved a 10-9 Democratic majority. Upon joining the Legislature, Mr. Mejias left the agency but became chairman of the Legislature's Economic Development Committee, overseeing his former agency and the rest of Mr. Sylver's department. He received $9,800 in campaign contributions from firms that benefited from the agency, either being hired to work for it or submitting projects that it approved. Mr. Mejias said the agency had already hired the firms before he arrived, called it ''squeaky clean'' and said, ''It's bringing in new business at a record rate.''
 $(6$)The Glen Cove law firm of Crowe Deegan, which donated $34,650 to Mr. Suozzi's county executive campaign. Without official authorization, the firm began working for the agency, shortly after Mr. Suozzi's election but before he actually took office. Without any competitive bidding, the agency later hired the firm retroactively and paid it $364,761. The firm also received another $402,026 from three other agencies under Mr. Sylver's control. H.U.D. is including $250,000 of that money in its demand for the repayment of nearly $1 million it says was misspent by Mr. Sylver or agencies under his control. 
 $(6$)Jon Kaiman, a Crowe Deegan lawyer who did legal work for the agency. Last fall he ran for office himself and is the new Democratic supervisor of North Hempstead town.
 $(6$)Robert Benrubi, another Crowe Deegan partner who was on the Suozzi transition team. He worked briefly on the county agency's staff and then joined another county agency payroll as a specialist in redeveloping polluted ''brownfields.'' He donated $300 to Mr. Mejias's campaign.
 $(6$)Zimmerman/Edelson, a Great Neck public relations firm that the county agency awarded a modest $14,387 contract for marketing and advertising. The firm's cofounder, Robert P. Zimmerman, is a member of the National Democratic Committee, a former candidate and a frequent party spokesman on television. His firm donated $2,500 to Mr. Suozzi's campaign. 
 Some of the hirings were contrary to Mr. Suozzi's general policy of cutting back fees for outside counsel and using staff lawyers instead. The agency records show that some firms were also hired without competitive bidding.
 Spending on personal services and other contracts, which totaled less than $500,000 a year in the Gulotta administration, has risen to about $700,000 under Mr. Suozzi, official filings show. For example, the agency paid $386,567 to the Garden City office of the law firm of Phillips Lytle, Hitchcock Blaine & Huber for bond counsel service. The statewide firm, which has a Garden City office and which worked for Glen Cove when Mr. Suozzi was its mayor, made seven campaign contributions totaling $41,550, of which Mr. Suozzi collected $39,600 and Mr. Mejias $1,950.
 While the biggest contracts went to Phillips Lytle and Crowe Deegan, smaller contracts included the Zimmerman/Edelson account and a $9,000 retainer for the accounting firm of Bloom & Company of Hempstead. It, too, donated to Mr. Suozzi's campaign, a total of $3,350.
 An audit in January of this year by the county comptroller, Howard S. Weitzman, a Democrat, criticized the Crowe Deegan contract. ''It had no spending cap or expiration date,'' he wrote. ''The I.D.A. failed to conduct or document any competitive process prior to hiring the firm or to require the disclosure or vetting of any potential conflict of interest or the appearance of the same.''
 ''The attorneys did not provide the number of hours worked on their invoice, and there is no evidence that the fees charged were reasonable or delineated in advance in the law firms engagement letter,'' the comptroller said. Likewise, the comptroller criticized the hiring process for Phillips Lytle: ''There was no evidence that any competitive procurement process was used to select this firm either.''
 Both law firms declined to comment, but Mr. Gioino said outside lawyers were retained for their expertise. ''The I.D.A. hired these firms based on their qualifications and their track record of getting results with other municipalities,'' he said. He added that their malpractice insurance shields the county from liability.
 Praising Crowe Deegan and Phillips Lytle, Mr. Suozzi described them as ''law firms that I trust, admire and respect and are qualified and do a very good job, whose abilities are beyond reproach.'' 
 He added: ''These are two firms that have known me for a long time. I've known them for a long time. They support me politically because they think I do a good job, and I hire them because I think they do a good job. That's it. That's the whole story, morning glory.''


CORRECTION-DATE: November 14, 2004

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 24 about Nassau County's Industrial Development Agency misstated the financing for two projects, the MONY offices at Lake Success and a motel in Plainview. They received private financing at regular rates, the agency says, not low-interest I.D.A. bonds. As reported, the agency granted tax breaks of $572,896 for MONY and $407,207 for the motel.

 The Inn at Plainview, left, a lot in Roslyn to be developed by Forest City Daly, and the Tweezerman facility in Port Washington, above, are among the projects that received benefits from the county's Industrial Development Agency. (Photographs by Vic DeLucia for The New York Times)(pg. 9)

SECTION: Section 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk; LIVING IN/Port Chester, N.Y.; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 1376 words

HEADLINE: A Village Takes Stock as More Retail Moves In

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
IN almost all ways but geographic, Port Chester, N.Y., stands far apart from its three well-heeled neighbors. While Rye and Harrison, N.Y., and Greenwich, Conn., are notable for their manicured lawns, leafy streets and quaint downtowns, most of Port Chester looks and feels more like a small city than the Westchester suburb it actually is. And unlike the surrounding communities, with their high per capita incomes, most of Port Chester's residents are working-class, and many are immigrants.
 For the last 100 years, Our Lady of the Rosary, a Roman Catholic church that overlooks the village from a perch near the Long Island Sound, has ministered to successive waves of newcomers. ''A small Ellis Island,'' was the way the Rev. Timothy Ploch, a priest at Our Lady of the Rosary, recently described the bustling village with its crowded multifamily houses and densely populated downtown.
 In the early and mid 1900's, Port Chester was home to Irish, Polish and Italian immigrants. Many of them found work at local factories like BeechNut LifeSavers, built homes and sent their children to public schools. 
 Nowadays, immigrants from Mexico, Peru, Guatemala and Ecuador live in those modest wood-frame houses. And because many of Port Chester's factories closed during the 1950's and early 60's, they work instead as electricians, landscapers and small business entrepreneurs in the affluent neighboring towns.
 Port Chester's strong Latino presence is most obvious in the downtown business district, where bodegas, beauty salons, bars and ethnic restaurants thrive in commercial buildings dating back to the first half of the previous century. An area of several blocks along North and South Main Streets and sections of Westchester Avenue, home to a variety of ethnic restaurants from take-out to white tablecloth establishments, has become a destination in recent years for diners from Connecticut and Westchester in search of Latin American specialties.
 ''I've seen the downtown change in many ways since I was a kid growing up here,'' said Charles J. Rosabella, who worked at an ice cream shop in the village in 1960, when he was attending the local high school. 
 ''I still remember some of those original stores,'' said Mr. Rosabella, who now owns Century 21 Rosabella Realty in the village. ''Most of them are long gone, although a handful of the old-timers are still around.''
 There is another type of change about to take place in Port Chester, as new construction for several big retailers proceeds, and the longstanding mom-and-pop character of the downtown shifts to the sidelines.
 Nowhere can the interface between the old and new in the village be better seen than at the corner of Westchester Avenue and North and South Main Streets, at the center of the business district along the waterfront. There, next to a 140,000-square-foot Costco store that opened several years ago, a 15-screen movie theater, a Super Stop & Shop and other discounters are to open within the year. 
 Gregg Wasser, a principal with G&S Investors in Old Bethpage, N.Y., the developer for the Waterfront, as the project is called, recently described the village and area around it as a ''region that is under-retailed.''
 As villagers look ahead to the opening of the outlets, many are wondering how the changes will affect them. For residents like Rob and Gail Rothweiler, homeowners in Port Chester for the last 15 years, the new construction promises long-awaited economic growth in the village and hopefully an increase in real estate values. 
 ''There's good value here already, and it will probably get even better now,'' said Mr. Rothweiler, a sales executive with AT&T. The Rothweilers own a four-bedroom, three-bath colonial home on a 0.75-acre lot in the village. ''With the new stores, more people will be coming to Port Chester and paying attention to it,'' Mr. Rothweiler said.
 But another homeowner, Jesus Condori, predicted the opposite. He worried that the increase in traffic generated by the new stores would depress property values.
 Mr. Condori, who immigrated to Port Chester from Arequipa, Peru, in 1989, is an electrician and the owner of a two-family home in the village. Although elected officials have widened and improved roads leading to the Waterfront, traffic still snarls. ''Things could become even more overcrowded,'' Mr. Condori said.
 Property values have been on the upswing in Port Chester in recent years. The median sales price for a single-family home in the village at the beginning of October was $535,000, up from $497,000 at the same time last year.
 Property values for homes in the village are 19 percent lower than they are for Westchester as a whole. At last count, the current median sales price for a single-family home in the county was $660,000.
 For a multifamily home in the village, the median sales price was $550,000, up from $497,500 a year ago.
 For condos, the median was $317,500, up from $260,000 in 2003. For co-ops, though, the median sales price in early October was $82,000, down from $97,000 a year ago, possibly because fewer of the more expensive two-bedroom units were sold in that period, Mr. Rosabella said.
 He predicted the new retail stores would generate more revenue for Port Chester, ease the tax burden for property owners and eventually attract new residents to the village. ''With the tax rate more stable and new businesses generating more jobs, we'll expect to see an improvement,'' he said. 
 Despite the optimistic predictions for the future vitality of the residential market, persistent problems in the village could deter some potential property owners.
 Joseph Krzeminski, Port Chester's police chief, reported that there is some overcrowding in older multifamily homes owned by absentee landlords and rented out to immigrants, a situation that poses potential fire and health hazards.
 Another worry for the police chief is the drunkenness that occurs at night and on weekends in the village, including among some of the undocumented workers. 
 And then there are unresolved legal matters, including complaints and federal lawsuits, related to eminent domain proceedings that the village instituted to clear property for the waterfront development. At times, stays were issued that halted construction. But for now, the work is continuing, said Liane Watkins, a lawyer in White Plains, who is a special counsel to the village with her father, John Watkins. 
 In the schools, the increase in the number of Hispanic residents living in the village is documented in enrollment percentages. In 1981, 21.2 percent of the Port Chester-Rye Union Free School District's 2,959 students were Hispanic, 52.4 percent were white, 25.1 percent were black and 1.3 percent were Asian. Last year, 66.2 percent of the district's 2,575 students were Hispanic, 23 percent were white, 9.8 percent were black, and 1 percent were Asian.
 Mr. Rothweiler said that he and his wife, who is active with the local parent-teachers organization, send their daughters, who are 8 and 11, to the public schools, because ''the numbers are reflective of what the real world is all about, and our kids are faring well.'' He and his wife both trace their roots to Italian forebears in Port Chester.
 The primary concern for Charles D. Coletti, the superintendent of schools, is the large group of students -- 25 percent in the district -- who do not speak English fluently and therefore require classes taught in their native language. ''It's a challenge,'' he said.
 The district has four elementary schools for kindergarten through fifth grade, a middle school for Grades 6 though 8, and a high school. With 60 percent of senior class students taking the SAT's last spring, the average score for the verbal section of the tests was 469; for the math section, the average was 476. Statewide average scores on the tests in 2003 were 496 for verbal and 510 for math. 
 The Rothweilers, who recently sold a Cape Cod house in Port Chester for twice what they paid for it 15 years ago, and bought another home nearby in the mid-$600,000's, said they plan to stay in the village.
 Mr. Rothweiler described his neighborhood as ''peaceful and quiet,'' the school system as solid, and Port Chester in general as ''a good place to raise children.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: 'ELLIS ISLAND' WITH SHOPPING -- Immigrants have long found a home in Port Chester, N.Y., but residents are wondering what new construction, above, will mean for life and property values there.

During the war, it was a natural distribution point for local farm produce. Afterward, it became a steamboat stop, the eastern ''port of Westchester,'' with its current name officially adopted in 1837.Map of New York State highlighting Port Chester.

LENGTH: 993 words

HEADLINE: Netanyahu Gets Tough to Transform Israel's Economy

BYLINE: By GREG MYRE

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
As Finance Minister Benjamin Netanyahu pushes to reshape Israel's economy, he makes a similar warning to almost everyone: expect to feel some pain.
 Mr. Netanyahu, a former prime minister and potentially a future one, has spared no one during his 19 months in his current post. 
 But he says an improving Israeli economy justifies his tough approach. 
 He considers it his duty to prod the poor to find jobs and to battle strike-prone unions that he says are dragging down the economy. 
 He tells middle-class Israelis they will have to live with reduced state benefits and warns the country's largest companies to brace themselves for a more competitive marketplace. 
 He is even calling for a modest cut in military spending despite the continuing struggle against the Palestinian uprising.
 When Mr. Netanyahu assumed his post last year, he often said that Israel's public sector accounted for 55 percent of the economy, while the private sector made up 45 percent, and that he intended to reverse that.
 In a country that is now mostly middle class but that has never completely abandoned its working-class roots, Mr. Netanyahu's efforts to make broad, market-oriented changes have met resistance at almost every turn.
 Prime Minister Ariel Sharon seldom speaks about economic issues at length and has granted Mr. Netanyahu, 55, broad latitude to handle financial affairs. But frequent protests against Mr. Netanyahu's policies may have political repercussions.
 In late September, the country had its third nationwide strike during Mr. Netanyahu's tenure, though it lasted just a day and a half. 
 Demonstrators opposed to his welfare cuts have maintained a presence in tents just outside the Finance Ministry for more than a year. 
 Shimon Peres, leader of the opposition Labor Party, has denounced the government's economic program as ''swinish capitalism.''
 But Mr. Netanyahu and his backers say his approach has contributed to an economic growth rate projected at 4 percent this year, compared with a growth rate of 1 percent in 2003 and declines of 1 percent in 2002 and 2001.
 Supporters also give credit to Mr. Netanyahu for substantial tax cuts, a stable currency, a sustained effort to chip away at the large public sector and improved domestic and international confidence in the economy.
 ''Israel's economy is on the right path, but the economy's car is still stuck in the mud, and we must continue to push it onto safe and dry ground,'' Mr. Netanyahu said recently. ''When we make it out of the mud, I want to make sure that everyone is in the car.''
 But critics say it is mostly the wealthy who have found seats in Mr. Netanyahu's vehicle. The technology industry appears to be recovering after a downturn that mirrored the one in the United States. 
 The stock market soared last year, and the top income tax rate for high-earning Israelis has dropped to 49 percent from 60 percent.
 Yet Israel's unemployment rate remains above 10 percent, and the Israeli news media frequently report on what they view as signs of worsening poverty, like long lines at soup kitchens.
 ''I view his program as very destructive,'' said Barbara Swirski, director of the Adva Center, a private research group in Tel Aviv that studies social issues. ''He tries to do everything in one giant step, and it damages the whole system.''
 Ms. Swirski cited the government's sharp cuts in welfare payments. She said she would support a welfare overhaul that included more training and employment opportunities. 
 ''But when you suddenly make a drastic cut in payments from one month to the next, you are going to hurt people,'' she said.
 Mr. Netanyahu is unapologetic. At a news conference in August to announce his planned budget for 2005, he said, ''We will continue to push the unemployed to go to work, because that is the way to eradicate poverty.''
 He says Israel cannot afford the level of benefits the state has been paying for decades. In a cut felt by every Israeli family, the government has reduced the monthly payment its sends to each household based on the number of children.
 This policy has encouraged large families. But with his customary bluntness, Mr. Netanyahu said families should not have more children than they could afford.
 ''He is determined to go with a free-market approach, but there has been so much resistance that he has not accomplished as much as he thought he could,'' said David Levhari, a professor of economics at Hebrew University in Jerusalem.
 Mr. Levhari said he generally supported Mr. Netanyahu's program, but predicted that the minister would continue to battle ingrained Israeli attitudes that favor a large government role in the economy.
 ''Israelis have the notion that the government should do something to solve their problems, not the market,'' Mr. Levhari said. 
 In September, a showdown between Mr. Netanyahu and Israel's powerful Histadrut labor federation was resolved, at least temporarily, when the National Labor Court ordered the end to a strike by 400,000 public-sector workers after one day.
 The court's ruling allowed both sides to claim a partial victory. The judge said the government must provide the money to pay nearly 20,000 municipal workers who have not received salaries for months.
 But the court also said that municipalities would have to agree to an economic recovery plan sought by Mr. Netanyahu, who has charged the local governments with widespread mismanagement. 
 Ezra Saban, a former director general of the Finance Ministry, said that Israel's economy had been opening up steadily for the last few decades, and that Mr. Netanyahu was pursuing a trend already in place, albeit with great gusto.
 ''The economy is becoming more market-oriented, and there is nothing the unions can do to stop it,'' said Mr. Saban, now a partner in an economic consulting firm in Israel. ''The business community here is much stronger than it used to be, and the unions no longer control things, as they did 20 to 25 years ago.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, second from left, says little about economic issues and has granted Benjamin Netanyahu, right, his finance minister and a former prime minister, broad latitude to handle financial affairs. (Photo by Gail Tibbon/Agence France-Presse--Getty Images)

HEADLINE: Is New York Losing Its Street Smarts?

BYLINE: By JOANNA SMITH RAKOFF. 
Joanna Smith Rakoff, a contributing editor and columnist for Poets and Writers magazine, is completing a novel set in Brooklyn.

 BODY:
ON a rainy night in April, a 24-year-old New Yorker named Jill Pittman left her weekly Bible study group in East Harlem, walked across town and took the subway to Harlem, where she shared an apartment with a college friend. As she walked home along her usual route, one block south on Lenox Avenue, and one block west on 134th Street, a hand closed firmly around her mouth and a soft voice uttered, ''Give me your money.'' 
 For a moment, Ms. Pittman thought her roommate's boyfriend, who lived nearby, was playing a joke on her. She had moved to the neighborhood six weeks earlier after a brief sojourn on the Upper West Side, and found it quiet and welcoming, full of families and friendly shopkeepers. 
 Then the assailant tightened his grip and repeated his command. A second assailant emerged from the darkness, yanked Ms. Pittman's messenger bag from across her chest, and fled. ''Walk that way and keep walking,'' the first man then whispered. She realized that this wasn't a joke. She had been mugged. 
 ''I felt a little silly when the police came,'' said Ms. Pittman, a friendly brunette from Kansas. ''You know, 134th Street is a dark street without much on it. They told me that one block north, 135th Street, it's a two-way street that's well lit. And it's a much more populated street, with shops and restaurants.'' 
 That Ms. Pittman had no qualms about walking solo down a dark, deserted street is a sign, certainly, of her rural roots. But it also speaks volumes on the major shift in the perception of New York. Over the last decade, as the homicide rate, for instance, dropped to a level not seen since 1963, as Bill Clinton settled into his Harlem office suite, and as even the most unlikely neighborhoods have been gentrified, the city's image has slowly evolved from Son of Sam to ''Sex and the City.'' 
 The bankrupt, graffiti-slathered, mugger-ravaged metropolis of the 70's, a cliche that lingered long after it bore only the faintest shred of accuracy, has emerged as an iridescent playland, with avenues lined with shops and bars, along which pretty young women might, and do, tromp about in six-inch stilettos. But has this happy turn for the city prompted the death of the street-smart New Yorker, once as large an urban figure as the opinionated cabby?
 ''My boyfriend, who grew up in Bed-Stuy, is always getting on me to be more careful with my wallet and where I put it in my bag,'' said Courtney Martin, a 24-year-old freelance writer who moved from Colorado to Manhattan in 1998 to attend Barnard College. ''It drives him crazy that I'm so trusting and optimistic. There is a part of me that feels like it is a self-fulfilling prophecy and if I do start to worry, I will bring on the bad luck.'' 
 Like many transplants in their 20's, Ms. Martin, now two years out of Barnard's cloistered confines, feels that her cellphone keeps her safe. ''I live in Windsor Terrace now, and I get on my cellphone whenever I walk home late at night by myself. Sometimes I will even just hold it up to my ear when I walk by people that look ominous. Silly, but somehow reassuring.'' 
 If Ms. Martin considers her precautions a bit silly, native New Yorkers find such cursory tactics, and the generally cavalier attitude that fuels them, both dangerous and, in a way, disrespectful to the city. Part of New York's charm, such natives believe, lies in its unconquerable dark side. 
 ''They need to know that it's not all magic,'' said Peter Shankman, a 32-year-old Manhattanite who wears his 1988 mugging outside La Guardia High School, near Lincoln Center, like a badge of honor. ''They're letting their guard down. Talking to people on the street without thinking about it. Taking the subway home late at night alone. No matter how good the city is, you can never forget that it's New York.'' 
 Eli B. Silverman, professor of police studies at John Jay College of Criminal Justice and author of ''N.Y.P.D. Battles Crime: Innovative Strategies in Policing'' (Northeastern University Press, 1999), detects a complete reversal of social perspective since the mugging era. ''In the old days, you assumed things were going to go wrong,'' he said, but today ''there's this blithe assumption that things are going to go right.'' The upside, he said, is the more that people are visible ''the less likely it is the bad guys are going to take over the streets.'' The downside, he added, is that people ''may put themselves at risk.''
 Kaari Pitkin, who moved to New York 10 years ago after graduating from Smith College in Northampton, Mass., knows about the downside. 
 Last December, while waiting for a train in the Borough Hall station in Downtown Brooklyn, Ms. Pitkin, a producer for WNYC, the city's public radio station, felt a tug on her shoulder and turned to find a man grabbing her wallet out of her open purse. ''Get your hand out of my bag!'' she yelled. The man quickly obeyed. 
 ''You would think I would have learned,'' she recalled recently with a laugh. ''But no.'' A month later, while shopping at the Key Food near her Park Slope apartment, a second pickpocket made a play for her wallet. This time she didn't notice until it was too late. ''I had shoved my wallet, probably really stupidly, in the open pocket of my coat. And I was talking on my cellphone and just generally being completely spacey and not paying attention to what was going on around me.'' 
 Recently, Ms. Pitkin has changed her attitude toward her own security, reverting to the warier behavior that marked her first years in New York. She is more aware of who is standing next to her and who is walking behind her. Still, she admitted, she sometimes leaves her bag open. ''I work in the news. We report on crime all the time. You know'' -- she lowers her voice to an announcer's baritone -- '''New York is now the safest city in the country. The lowest crime rate ever.' I kind of take that stuff to heart and don't get too worked up about things.'' 
 Despite the still-souring economy, crime rates have continued to drop, in part because of even more basic changes in the city. 
 ''It's about gentrification,'' said Nancy Mahon, a lawyer who headed the Center on Crimes, Communities and Culture, part of the Soros Foundations Network, for five years. ''Quality-of-life stuff. The city looks better, and people feel better. The fabric of the city has changed.'' Some wonder if the current low level of street crime might not have something to do with the attacks of Sept. 11, which caused an unprecedented solidarity among New Yorkers of all stripes. 
 In a twist, the fear of just such another terrorist attack may be what has eclipsed many New Yorkers' fear of an everyday mugging. ''People have shifted their attention away from street crime to terrorism and more serious crime,'' said Christopher Falkenberg, a former Secret Service agent who now runs Insite Security, a Midtown consulting firm that caters to corporations and affluent families. ''They're less worried about open backpacks and pickpockets than they are about bombings.'' 
 Meanwhile, Ms. Pittman, the onetime Kansas farm girl, is living a little more defensively these days. After the mugging, she had long discussions about basic self-defense with her roommate's boyfriend, who, as it happened, had been mugged two months earlier. Now, Ms. Pittman keeps to well-lighted streets when she's alone, and tries to walk with friends whenever possible. If she hears someone approaching from behind, she turns and meets that person's gaze. When riding the subway, she avoids empty cars. 
 ''I carry myself differently now,'' she says, with pride. ''At the time, I'd only been in the neighborhood six weeks and I didn't feel comfortable there. Now, I feel like I belong.''

PERSON: Joanna Smith Rakoff

LENGTH: 1275 words

HEADLINE: Heirlooms, Yes, but Without the Looming Heirs

BYLINE: By SUSAN B. GARLAND

 BODY:
EIGHT years ago, when Barbara and John Mich decided to move from their 10-room house to an apartment half the size in Canton, Mass., they asked their six adult children to take many of the possessions they had accumulated over the years.
 The children came home to choose among those belongings -- like a grandmother's red marble table, a great-grandparent's china set and even a small ceramic Christmas tree that the family decorated each year with gumdrops. In many cases, the items may have had more sentimental than financial value.
 Mrs. Mich, 73, says she and her husband intend to give away more things over the next few years and to leave a list of the rest as part of their estate. Several of her children have already expressed interest in particular items. ''I think that if they want something and it means something to them, they should have it,'' she said. 
 In many other families, dividing the furniture, dishes, and assorted tchotchkes of a loved one doesn't go this smoothly. Parents usually leave it to their heirs to divide personal property after their deaths, giving their already overwrought children the challenge of splitting grandfather's beloved watch three ways. Instead, say people with experience in estate planning or division, the best way to avoid hurt feelings, lifelong rifts and even lawsuits is to include the children ahead of time, as the Miches did.
 ''Personal effects are so freighted with emotional issues that the real battle is waged over who gets the photograph albums rather than the $30 million,'' said Jon Gallo, an estate planning lawyer in Los Angeles who, with his wife, Eileen, a psychotherapist, conducts seminars on the emotional issues tied to family wealth.
 Family squabbles over belongings are nothing new, of course. But the questions are becoming more complex as the structures of many families change: How do you ensure that your stepchildren receive something special? If you remarry later in life, should Grandmother's crystal go to your new spouse or to your adult daughter? 
 Though the subject can be touchy, experts say, parents and adult children should talk about the transfer of personal property and make some distribution decisions well before problems escalate.
 ''It's absolutely acceptable for the parents to say, 'We have a lot of stuff here, and at some point, it's going to be yours, so let's talk about this now,''' said Linda Hetzer, co-author, with Janet Hulstrand, of ''Moving On: A Practical Guide to Downsizing the Family Home'' (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, 2004). They wrote the book after helping their fathers move to smaller homes, and after talking with many families. If parents don't raise the subject, Ms. Hetzer said, grown children should dismiss any concerns about appearing greedy and broach the issue themselves.
 The discussions can go a long way toward averting misunderstandings, experts say. While some parents make no provision in their wills for personal possessions, others bequeath certain items without stating the reasons for their decisions. Either way, childhood conflicts can resurface. 
 ''It may play out as, 'They knew I wanted this and they gave it to my sibling, and this proves Mom loved you best,''' said Marlene S. Stum, associate professor of family economics at the University of Minnesota. ''It helps to explain to your children why you decided to give a gift to a caregiver or reward a child who helped out financially.'' 
 In 1999, the university extension service released ''Who Gets Grandma's Yellow Pie Plate'' (www.yellowpieplate.umn.edu), a workbook and video intended to help families make decisions on passing on personal property; Dr. Stum was the lead researcher and author for the project.
 Because each family is different, no single system works for everyone. Some families agree that all members should get the same treatment -- to the point that each child receives the same dollar value of appraised items. But others may decide, for example, to give a little extra to the daughter who helped her parents the most, or to a nephew who is struggling financially. 
 Once the subject is raised, a good way for parents to start is to ask the children if there are particular items they want. If a family is lucky, the wish lists won't overlap. Another popular method of distribution is a round robin in which family members take turns choosing objects.
 In one family, Ms. Hulstrand recalled, all the adult children placed colored stickers on items they wanted, and the parents kept track in a notebook. When an item had more than one sticker, the children worked it out. ''If someone thought one person was claiming too much, they could look in the notebook and see what was fair,'' Ms. Hulstrand said.
 Parents can appraise items of financial value and separate them from those of purely sentimental worth; then the children make requests from one list at a time. That way, the silver service doesn't end up on the same list as the turkey-shaped salt shaker. It may be best for the parents to leave children's spouses or the grandchildren out of the decision making, even if parents eventually set aside special gifts for them. 
 Parents may be surprised by some of the choices. ''They see their assumptions were off base,'' Dr. Stum said. ''You may think Janey will love your thimble collection, but Janey may not care at all, and parents usually want possessions to go to someone who really values them.''
 A discussion also allows parents to share the history behind certain objects. ''The stories can make the things very special, and sometimes the stories are more important than the items,'' Ms. Hulstrand said. Often, parents use such occasions to offer gifts early; the good dishes, for instance, might go to the child who has taken over the holiday dinners. 
 Colleen Barney, an estate lawyer in Irvine, Calif., said parents should make a list of who is getting what, then make sure the will refers to it. By keeping the list separate from the will, parents have the flexibility to change their minds without having to rewrite the will each time. 
 If you want to make gifts to people outside the immediate family -- friends, nieces or stepchildren -- make sure they are listed, said Ms. Barney, the co-author, with Victoria Collins, of ''Best Intentions: Ensuring Your Estate Plan Delivers Both Wealth and Wisdom'' (Dearborn Trade, 2002). If you remarry and want to leave certain belongings to your children, she said, write it down.
 Such early decision making can be a big relief for children. A woman from Fairfield County, Conn., who asked that her name not be used, said that every time her mother bought a piece of jewelry, she would decide whether it would go to her or to her sister -- and would then record the choice on a list with two columns.
 When her mother died a decade ago, the two sisters divided the items accordingly. The list removed a burden at an already difficult time.
 ''We didn't have to deal with choosing,'' the woman said. ''She always tried to make things easy for her children.''

QUICK READ
Here are considerations for dividing personal property in an estate:

UNDERSTAND family members' attachments to certain possessions. Take your time, and encourage other family members to talk openly.

DECIDE what is fair. Should everyone be treated equally, regardless of their contribution, need or marital status?

SEPARATE financially valuable items from sentimentally valuable ones. If you and others want some of the same things, take turns choosing from each list.

BE practical. Give the piano, for example, to a grandchild who likes music.

DON'T make decisions immediately after a funeral. Let emotions settle.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Barbara and John Mich of Canton, Mass., expect to give the china they received as a wedding gift in 1954 to one of their daughters. (Photo by Jodi Hilton for The New York Times)

ORGANIZATION: UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA (59%) University of Minnesota

PERSON: Marlene S Stum; Susan B Garland

LENGTH: 1056 words

HEADLINE: Miss Subways, Subversive and Sublime

BYLINE: By MELANIE BUSH. 
Melanie Bush, a former writer for The Village Voice, has recently completed a novel called ''Money Makes It Clean,'' about journalists and sex workers during the makeover of Times Square.

 BODY:
RIDING the D train to Sheepshead Bay in the 1970's, I knew I would never be Miss America. Not just because I was short, Jewish and nerdily bespectacled by the time I was 8. No, it was something more enigmatic than that, and even less changeable: Even as an 8-year-old, I sensed the complete and irrevocable impossibility of anyone who rode the D train ever becoming Miss America. Burdened -- tainted -- with intimate knowledge of the D train, I could never grow up into that ideal of disinterested equanimity all Miss Americas should embody.
 But so what? I could become Miss Subways. 
 From 1941 to 1977, a company called New York Subways Advertising sponsored the Miss Subways contest. Applicants, ranging in age from 14 to 30, all purportedly riders of the subway, sent their photos and biographies to John Robert Powers, a top modeling agent. The lucky winner had her face, along with a blurb about her life and ambitions, plastered in every car of the IND, IRT and BMT for one month.
 The contest has been revived and Miss Subways' daughters, making their debut as Ms. Subways on a system that celebrates its 100th anniversary this week, will no doubt maintain their forerunners' pedigree. Unlike Miss America, these queens represented the full spectrum of their constituency, mainly Irish, Italian, Latina and Jewish. The first black winner reigned on the trains in 1947 (36 years before a black Miss America), the first Asian in 1949. 
 Dressed up and itching between my parents on those rush-hour D trains to Grandma's shabbes dinner, I gazed into Miss Subways' calm, confident eyes. Would my sisters attain the goals their blurbs so assertively stated, though they, too, had the mark of the subway upon them? Was this just another dumb beauty contest? And what did it all mean for me? 
 Thirty years later, I paid a visit to the old Miss Subways posters at Ellen's Stardust Diner. Ellen Hart Sturm, Miss Subways of March 1959, told me that Miss Subways was created to ''put a little glamour in the subways, something to cheer people up.'' Bernard Spaulding, who supervised the contest in its last 14 years, claimed that the contest was simply a ploy by Subways Advertising to ''increase the eye traffic for adjoining ads.''
 But for whose benefit was this glamour, I wonder. Which people were being cheered up? Whose eyes were being seduced to drink the message of adjacent advertisers at the dawn of World War II as the men marched off to fight? 
 It's no secret that in eras when women gain greater economic mobility -- often, historically, during wartime -- the thing Naomi Wolf has called the beauty myth gets shoved down our throats with heightened vigor. It's also true that the Miss Subways posters -- carrying the tag line ''Look around this car! Next month's selection may be riding with you!'' -- overtly functioned like beauty advertising aimed at women everywhere: Divide and conquer, instill self-doubt.
 But the posters were also covertly feminist, sometimes shockingly so, even to me, a child of the 70's. From the first (''Mona Freeman, wants to be a top notch freelance illustrator'') to the last (''Heidi Hafner Her goal: a flight instructor's rating''), they focused on women's ambitions, and in the 1940's or the 70's or now, that's a rare rose to find clamped in the teeth of mass advertising. Yet there it was, and there it more or less firmly remained, probably because the contest was structured during World War II, when more than three million women were offered paying work for the first time, and were thus riding the subways, not to mention operating them, in much greater numbers than before. Connoting glamour in work was a useful tool in industry's campaign to enlist them. 
 The posters were at their most radical during the war years, and reflect women's later return to the home. Miss Subways' journey tracks a clear underground parallel to the prescribed roles of her sisters' above: While the civilian women of World War II may have been crucial to the work force, the purpose of housewives, as Betty Friedan puts it, ''is to buy more things for the house.'' 
 From the exhilarating peak of December 1942's Marguerite McAuliffe, ''whose aim is to be a doctor as good as her dad,'' and November 1943's Cecile Woodley, whose ''main interests are her job and the Navy enthusiastically O.K.'s skiing, Mozart and Katharine Hepburn,'' we slide submissively toward Irene Scheidt, June 1950, whose ''fondest hope is a trip to Bermuda.'' Then up we go again to Eleanor Nash, November 1960, ''young, beautiful, and expert with a rifle.''
 SEEING the ad cards again at Ellen's, I was jolted back to the thrilling ride that Miss Subways offered to a young, identity-seeking passenger. My eyes weren't ''trafficked'' to the ads. I didn't care about bleaching my mustache or learning to type. What I waited for each new month was: What did she do? What were her goals? The Miss Subways I wanted to be was the airplane pilot. Or how about ''travel writer''? ''Scientist''? ''Surgeon''? Right there on the subway! For me, any mention of their appearance flew back into oblivion like dead planets. Maybe next month she'd plan to be an astronaut. Or president! 
 What was actually going on here, I saw, was women, real New York women, talking to each other about their intentions and transmitting these messages through the medium of some men's advertising campaign. And where were they doing it? Underground! Miss Subways became one more game to decipher, one more code to crack. Even the name had a double-toned ring for those who could hear it: Miss Sub Ways. Subterfuge. Subversive. Sublime.
 That their standard of beauty was realistic didn't hurt, either: It jibed with the girl I saw in the mirror and made their goals seem real too. Unlike Miss America, these women would build real lives on what they accomplished in the real world, not in some shifting netherworld of male fantasy. 
 They talked to me on the D train, these queens of rapid transit, with a telepathic elbow jab to the ribs. ''Sure, we'll let them doll us up; they can't see what we're really doing. But we know where we're going, kid, and when we get there, there'll be room for you too.'' Those ethnic, ambitious beauties, often rendered ''beautiful'' by fairly obvious photographic or cosmetic techniques, they winked at me when no one was looking.


GRAPHIC: Photos (Photographs by Nicholas Hegel McClelland for The New York Times
 insets above left and top right from ''Subways: The Tracks That Built New York City'' by Lorraine B. Diehl [Clarkson Potter]) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ORGANIZATION: Ellen's Stardust Diner (Nyc Restaurant)

PERSON: Melanie Bush; Ellen Hart Strum

GEOGRAPHIC: NEW YORK, NY, USA (93%) NEW YORK, USA (93%) UNITED STATES (93%) New York City

LENGTH: 1479 words

HEADLINE: Wheel Is Turning Against S.U.V.'s

BYLINE: By JANE GORDON

 BODY:
ABOUT once a month, without fail, as Bryan Feery drives his Hummer around Glastonbury, somebody holds up a hand as he passes by. The person isn't waving.
 ''Oh absolutely, I get the finger from people,'' he said.
 Such hostility is a more visible sign of the backlash against sport utility vehicles. Since 1989, when sales of the vehicles really took off, Hummer dealerships have been torched, environmental groups have lobbied against S.U.V.'s, and books have examined their flaws. Never mind what the neighbors think. 
 ''I hate them,'' Kay Frangione of Southington said recently as she was helping her daughter and two grandchildren out of her Honda Accord at the Westfield Shoppingtown mall in Meriden. ''I cannot see over them. And I think there's a general personality that goes with the car, if you know what I mean.''
 Some car manufacturers call the driver's seat in an S.U.V. ''the command position,'' and the bulk of the vehicles intimidate some drivers of smaller cars, inflaming passions in a way that tractor-trailers and pickup trucks never did. The Sierra Club, the environmental group, has called the tension on the roadways between the vehicles and passenger cars ''the Survival of the Fattest.'' Indeed, a New Britain woman who asked that her name not be used, keeps a pad and paper in her sedan as tools in her battle with S.U.V.'s. 
 ''I take their license plate numbers down now,'' said the woman, who has twice called police on her cellphone to report aggressive S.U.V. drivers. ''They just expect you to move over, even if there's no place to go. And I've been noticing they're even worse in bad weather. They just want me to get out of their way.''
 Michael Marsden, the dean of St. Norbert College in Wisconsin who has taught a course on automobiles and American pop culture, said he has never seen such anger directed against a vehicle. 
 ''Nobody has seen a backlash against motor homes, or pickup trucks, both equally inefficient with fuel,'' he said. ''I think the symbology of the S.U.V. is the issue. From some points of view they are excessive. A lot of people believe in their minds that these cars are safer for their families. They see more from the driver's seat, they feel above traffic problems, so they are looking at it from another lens. But for running around town, they don't make a lot of sense.''
 And there are practical concerns. Despite their perception of being safer than passenger cars, S.U.V.'s have a greater chance of rolling over in a single-car accident than any other vehicle. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration reported in August that people in sport utility vehicles in 2003 had nearly an 11 percent greater chance of dying in an accident than people in cars.
 Insurance groups also cite accident incompatibility, in which many S.U.V. bumpers do not match up to passenger car bumpers, as a primary cause of escalating insurance costs for all cars. And with the price of gas above $2 a gallon, S.U.V.'s, especially the ones that get 11 to 14 miles a gallon, are becoming expensive to drive.
 ''I'm getting eight feet to the gallon with this car,'' said William Tyler, a sergeant with the Farmington Police Department, about his Dodge Durango. ''I can hardly afford the gas. When I'm driving, I literally can see the gas gauge moving.'' He said he was thinking of selling it.
 Sales of S.U.V.'s still remain solid, but there has been a softening of sales for the larger ones. That has forced many manufactures to offer cash incentives to buyers to keep the bigger S.U.V.'s moving.
 At Griffin Ford in Greenwich, buyers are still going directly to an S.U.V., the Ford Explorer, when they come in, said Jerry Cooper, general manager. The Explorer is Ford's best-selling vehicle, but the larger Expedition, and the largest, the Excursion, are barely selling, even with incentives
 ''The Explorer is our bread and butter,'' Mr. Cooper said. ''The market for the Excursion is very, very soft in this area of the country. It's primarily selling in the Southwest, for towing other vehicles.''
 Robert Scungio, the general sales manager of Branch Toyota in Watertown, said the smaller S.U.V.'s, such as the RAV4, the Highlander and the 4Runner, are selling, but not the Sequoia, one of Toyota's largest S.U.V.'s. 
 ''The bigger cars are flat,'' he said. ''I honestly can tell you that Sequoia sales are not hot. The smaller S.U.V.'s are what are selling here.''
 Sales of the Hummer, one of the largest S.U.V.'s on the road, are down 20 percent nationwide through September compared with the same period last year, according to the National Automobile Dealers Association. The novelty of the military-inspired vehicle hasn't worn off for Mr. Feery, though. He went from a Ford Expedition to his Hummer, which he bought more than a year ago.
 When Mr. Feery stops at a gas station, other drivers often approach him to ask about his gas mileage. Eleven miles to the gallon, with a 32-gallon tank, he tells them. Mr. Feery defended his purchase, saying he works with developers and must navigate unpaved roads on construction sites regularly.
 ''Besides, I like the look of it,'' he said. ''I enjoy nice cars.''
 Others owners, like Sergeant Tyler, want to get rid of their S.U.V.'s, but have had trouble finding any takers.
 ''We're getting away from gas guzzlers,'' said Ken Maynard of Enfield, who has been listing his Chevy Suburban in newspaper classifieds for weeks. ''This car isn't terrible on gas; it's a little bit better than the older ones. But I haven't had one call.''
 Pia Slivinski of Willimantic has been trying to sell her Jeep Grand Cherokee for weeks, too.
 ''I really like the vehicle,'' said Ms. Slivinski, who uses the car to commute to work. ''But I'm paying a ridiculous amount of money to keep it; $400 a month on insurance, and it's stupid to spend so much money on gas.''
 Car buyers have been increasingly turning to the smaller, car-based utility wagons, known as crossovers, or C.U.V.'s. They include the Toyota Highlander, the Honda Pilot and the Lexus RX330, which are built on a car frame but still offer four-wheel drive, said Paul Taylor, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers' Association in Virginia.
 ''The truck-based S.U.V.'s heyday was 1989 to '99,'' Mr. Taylor said. ''The C.U.V.'s have been strong since 2000. It seems like a compromise; crossover vehicles that park in a normal spot at McDonald's or the mall.''
 Sales of crossover vehicles grew 34.9 percent in 2003, compared to 2002, as sales of truck-based S.U.V.'s declined by 3.7 percent. Mr. Taylor said he believed sales will grow by at least 40 percent next year for the crossovers, while truck-based S.U.V. sales will decline or remain flat. The automobile dealers association does not track statewide sales figures.
 Nona Aubin of Cheshire owns both a Nissan Altima and a Nissan Xterra sports utility. She said she felt vulnerable on the highway with the Altima. ''So we take the S.U.V. on the highway,'' she said.
 Mr. Marsden of St. Norbert College, who has a home in snowy northern Michigan and owns three sport utility vehicles, said many people feel that way, including himself.
 ''The S.U.V. is the contemporary equivalent of the Conestoga wagon in the 19th century,'' he said. ''It was the wagon that crossed the western plains. The S.U.V. is the security blanket for the 21st century. We have a long history of needing to tame our landscape. I know this sounds like an overstatement, but once we closed the American frontier, we had to find a new frontier, and the highway, the motor scape, is the new frontier. A lot of this is metaphoric, but people are willing to spend a lot of money on symbolism.'' 
 Some drivers of cars said that they have noticed that S.U.V. owners drive aggressively and are fighting back by being aggressive themselves. Catherine Gooley of Wethersfield said S.U.V. drivers often cut her off in her Buick Century, an older-model midsized car. After years of doing nothing, she now honks and yells at offenders. Still, she said, she thought her actions were fruitless.
 ''I don't think they hear me, because it's not making any difference,'' she said. ''S.U.V. drivers think they're driving 18-wheelers out there.'' 
 Betty Wolf of Hamden, who drives a Toyota Camry, said she believed S.U.V.'s should be banned. But she was loath to tell her son-in-law, who owned one, how she felt.
 ''I really wish they would stop making them,'' she said as she walked to her car in the Westfield Shoppingtown parking lot. ''They're bad on gas, I can't see around them, they topple over in accidents. Yet so many people have them.''
 Across the lot, Bob Chiapponi of Middletown gazed admiringly at a big Chevy Tahoe parked across from his smaller Blazer. ''I used to hate these things,'' he said. ''Now I love them. I don't care what people think; I worry about me. I'm thinking, maybe, a Toyota Sequoia.''
