SECTION: Section W; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 890 words

HEADLINE: Resentment Toward G.M. Is Growing In Germany

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
Is General Motors jilting Germany for Poland because of the war in Iraq?
 A German politician suggested as much last week, saying in a radio interview that G.M.'s Opel division had shifted some auto production from its plants in Germany to a factory in Gliwice, Poland, to reward the Polish government for its support of the Bush administration.
 G.M. dismisses political motives, noting that Poland's far lower labor costs give it a compelling economic incentive to move. But this is only one of several brickbats General Motors has had to absorb in the 11 days since it announced that it would cut up to 12,000 jobs in Europe, the majority in Germany. 
 The cover of this week's Stern newsmagazine has a picture of a red, white and blue cowboy boot crushing a crowd of Opel workers. Stamped on the boot's sole is the G.M. logo. The magazine describes General Motors as the ''brand killer from Detroit,'' using ''Wild West'' methods.
 General Motors is no stranger to bad publicity in the wake of layoffs. But in Germany, the company's painful moves have coincided with a fraught period in German-American relations. It is little surprise that the anger at G.M.'s cutbacks has taken on an anti-American flavor.
 The company's blunt warning of job losses also ruffled feathers in a country with a long history of worker-management comity. Strikes are illegal and labor talks follow time-honored rituals. German carmakers like Volkswagen and DaimlerChrysler have resisted deep cuts in their payrolls, at least in their home country.
 General Motors, critics said, ignored these rules, which compounded its problems. 
 Rather than thrashing out its cuts in advance with Opel's union and workers' councils, as is the custom in German companies, G.M. announced them directly to the employees and the news media.
 The company further rankled workers by not dispatching an executive to the Opel factory in Bochum to explain its decision. The factory, in the economically depressed Ruhr Valley, is viewed as the most likely to be shut down. Workers there staged a six-day strike to protest the cuts.
 ''I don't think they know anything about Europe, otherwise they would have done things completely differently,'' said Ferdinand Dudenhoffer , director of the Center for Automotive Research in Gelsenkirchen. ''I've never seen such lousy communication at such a difficult moment.''
 Executives at General Motors said they communicated directly with workers in the interests of transparency. At German carmakers, such labor negotiations are often carried out behind closed doors, with union leaders leaking the company's plans to the news media before the company.
 ''We pledge to speak to our employees first,'' a spokesman for G.M. Europe, Tony Cervone, said. ''We're handling this in a way that is consistent with the level of integrity we value as a company. That's based on a corporate culture that transcends national boundaries.''
 G.M. did not send someone to Bochum, Mr. Cervone said, because the company felt it would not be safe, given the emotion of the workers. The strike, though brief, reverberated through Opel's other plants because the Bochum factory makes components that are used throughout Europe.
 Under German law, General Motors must reach an agreement with Opel's workers before putting its cost-cutting plan into effect. The workers are demanding that no plants be closed, and that no one be laid off involuntarily. G.M. said it could reach its goal of reducing costs by 500 million euros ($630 million) a year without closing factories, but it has not ruled out forced layoffs.
 Analysts say G.M. has no choice but to reduce its head count in Europe sharply. ''They have a top-line problem because their image is so bad that they can't sell their cars,'' said Arndt Ellinghorst, an analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein in Frankfurt. ''They really misread the market.''
 Other carmakers have opted to cut more generous deals with their employees. DaimlerChrysler, after threatening to move production to South Africa, signed a deal with its union, IG Metall, that provides smaller wage increases and more flexible work rules. But it did not cut jobs.
 The company said the deal would reduce its labor costs by 500 million euros a year by 2006, the same amount as G.M. Mr. Ellinghorst and other analysts said they doubted it would save that much.
 Despite the criticisms leveled at General Motors, there are signs that its tougher style may become more common in Germany. KarstadtQuelle, a financially troubled department store chain, recently announced 5,500 job cuts, as part of an overhaul of the company.
 Volkswagen is in tense negotiations with IG Metall over a contract for 103,000 assembly line workers. The company is demanding a two-year wage freeze, and warns that unless it reduces its labor costs by a third over the next six years, 30,000 jobs could be in jeopardy.
 Volkswagen has not announced a single layoff, however, and it is pledging an across-the-board job guarantee if the union accepts its deal. Analysts say that Volkswagen, as a German company partly owned by the state of Lower Saxony, does not have G.M.'s freedom.
 ''Volkswagen and Lower Saxony will do anything to secure jobs,'' Mr. Ellinghorst said. ''If market conditions continue like this for another few years, they will have similar cost problems as Opel.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Workers at G.M.'s Opel plant in Bochum, Germany, protesting the company's plan to cut up to 12,000 jobs. G.M. has also been criticized for making its decision without negotiations, which is against German custom. (Photo by Frank Augstein/Associated Press)

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; National Desk; THE AD CAMPAIGN; Pg. 21

LENGTH: 545 words

HEADLINE: Bush Camp's Greatest Hits

BYLINE: By JIM RUTENBERG

 BODY:

This advertisement for President Bush began running in at least a dozen battleground states on Monday.

PRODUCER: Maverick Media.

THE SCRIPT: A narrator says: ''President Bush and Congressional allies: strong leadership to protect America; tax relief; common sense health care; strengthen and protect Social Security. John Kerry and liberal allies: higher taxes; voting to tax Social Security benefits; government-run health care; a record of slashing intelligence; and reckless defense cuts. Alone in the booth, why take the risk?'' President Bush says, ''I'm George W. Bush and I approve this message.''

ON THE SCREEN: The spot opens on a presidential ballot. The choices underneath ''President Bush and Congressional Allies'' are ''strong leadership,'' ''tax relief,'' ''common sense health care'' and ''strengthen and protect Social Security.'' As red check marks appear in each of those boxes the screen flashes a progression of happy Americans: a little girl, a blue-collar worker, an old man in a sun hat, a woman with graying hair. When it says ''John Kerry and liberal allies in Congress'' the choices are ''higher taxes,'' ''voting to tax Social Security,'' ''government-run health care,'' ''slashing intelligence'' and ''reckless defense cuts.'' This time, the progression of Americans look decidedly less pleased: a father with his son; an elderly woman; a woman and a little boy in a batter's helmet. The spot ends showing Mr. Bush and his wife, Laura, casually dressed.

ACCURACY: Mr. Kerry has promised to raise taxes, but only on those earning more than $200,000 a year. Mr. Kerry and other Democrats voted to increase the number of people who would have to pay taxes on Social Security benefits, but they did so as part of former President Bill Clinton's 1993 package to reduce the budget deficit, which some economists credit with setting the stage for the record economic expansion that followed. Mr. Kerry is not proposing ''government-run health care.'' His plan would expand existing government-run programs like Medicare to help cover the uninsured. But independent experts say his plan would not affect 97 percent of the public. Mr. Kerry did propose capping intelligence spending for five years in 1994, a year after the first terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, but for two of those years intelligence spending did not reach the levels of the proposed cap anyway. Mr. Kerry has voted for eliminating or ceasing production of several weapons programs. But Vice President Dick Cheney moved to end many of the same programs when he was defense secretary for Mr. Bush's father.

SCORECARD: This is a sort of greatest-hits compilation of attacks Mr. Bush's campaign has made against Mr. Kerry all year. Like past advertisements in which many of these charges have been made, it will probably have mixed success. Some voters have said they are concerned that Mr. Kerry is proposing a government takeover of health care, despite news media reports calling this accusation overblown. Attacks on Mr. Kerry's credentials to be commander in chief seem to have helped Mr. Bush maintain a lead in polls when it comes to who would better protect the nation, but not enough to give him the sort of decisive lead his strategists would have liked. JIM RUTENBERG


GRAPHIC: Photo 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: US SOCIAL SECURITY (91%); TAXES & TAXATION (91%); TAX LAW (90%); US PRESIDENTS (90%); SOCIAL SECURITY (90%); PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (90%); VOTERS & VOTING (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (90%); POLITICAL ADVERTISING (90%); GOVERNMENT HEALTH INSURANCE (89%); TAX RELIEF (89%); LIBERALISM (89%); US DEMOCRATIC PARTY (78%); ELECTIONS (78%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (77%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (77%); US PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (77%); SENIOR CITIZENS (77%); TAX INCREASES (77%); BUDGETS (77%); POLITICAL PARTIES (76%); MEDICARE (76%); DEFENSE DEPARTMENTS (71%); MILITARY WEAPONS (71%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (62%); TERRORIST ATTACKS (60%); BUDGET DEFICITS (60%); TERRORISM (50%) Presidential Election of 2004; Election Issues; Political Advertising

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: OHIO; Pg. 23

LENGTH: 1498 words

HEADLINE: The Intense Battle for the Hearts and Minds of Voters Takes Its Toll in Stark County

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Voters in this battleground of battlegrounds know they should feel lucky. 
 The presidential candidates have seriously contested less than half of the nation. But for Stark County, a political bellwether, the nation's politics are so local that a commercial promoting Senator John Kerry holds up Canton as an example of job loss under George W. Bush. 
 President Bush has been to Canton twice in four months, most recently on Friday. His sister, Dorothy Bush Koch, spoke here on Saturday. Senator John Edwards campaigned here on Wednesday. 
 Yet if the political attention is more intense in Stark County, so are the political turmoil and anxiety. Voters here say they feel more interested and involved than in previous campaigns, but also more depleted. 
 ''It's a terrific experience,'' Michael Pastrikos, 51, said of the hometown politicking. ''It shows respect, and it makes sure the candidates understand what the issues are.''
 Yet Mr. Pastrikos said he could not wait for this terrific experience to be over. Why? ''The pressure and the stress, and the damage they've caused on television,'' he said.
 With political advertisements interrupting gardening shows on the radio and soap operas on television, the campaign has washed into every corner of life here, touching even one of the most hallowed of escapes -- high school football. Mr. Pastrikos spoke at halftime Saturday night, as the McKinley Bulldogs paused in demolishing the Hoover Vikings at Fawcett Stadium, on the campus of the Pro Football Hall of Fame. 
 Before the game, Ohio Republican Party workers passed out cards bearing a picture of Mr. Bush with Chris Spielman, the former Ohio State University and Cleveland Browns star. ''Evil can only exist if good people do nothing,'' Mr. Spielman was quoted as saying, urging a vote for the president.
 Standing with a friend who supports Mr. Bush, Mr. Pastrikos, a Kerry supporter, argued that most commentators had it backward: It was not the voters of the county or the nation who were so at odds, but the candidates who were deliberately driving them apart.
 ''Our country's being divided by this,'' he said. ''And it's sad.''
 It is a little poignant that, while elections are meant to crystallize the highest American ideals of democracy, the language connected to them is of death and destruction: states are battlegrounds; volunteers are ground troops; advertising is an air war. By that metaphoric standard, it seems both campaigns felt compelled this year to destroy Stark County in order to save it. 
 The Cleveland media market, which includes Stark County, has had more spending on presidential advertisements during this election -- more than $40 million -- than did all of Ohio in 2000, said Evan Tracey, of the Campaign Media Analysis Group in Arlington, Va. ''Cleveland, Ohio, has been essentially the eye of the storm,'' he said. In places like this, he said, ''it's gone beyond just trying to touch voters, and it's almost trying to become invasive to voters, to get into every aspect of their lives.''
 Beyond the candidates and their parties, groups like the National Air Traffic Controllers Association are also weighing in, pushing their own agendas and complaints -- in the controllers' case, that Mr. Bush has not hired more of them. (''If a mountain is rapidly approaching, please press 1,'' a recorded voice is heard saying, as a jumbo jet is shown in the clouds. ''Otherwise, please hold.'') 
 Swelling the commercial cacophony on television are office-seekers as local as state representative and county commissioner.
 ''I'll be glad when I can turn on the television and not see a political ad,'' said Jeannie Freitag, 58, a retired teacher. ''Bringing the campaign here, that was good. But the advertising is awful.''
 Despite the dawn-to-dawn barrage of advertisements, voters here do not seem particularly cynical. If anything, they are taking the campaign even more seriously. But they wonder if Canton's image has been damaged by it, and if the divides that have opened up will soon close. They wonder if their concerns will remain the winners' concerns after Election Day.
 ''I hope they don't forget about us,'' said Sandy Zeiger, 33, a dental hygienist, as she ate dinner Friday night at John's Bar and Grille.
 Her friend Karen Hoffman, 36, said the stakes were so high that she could scarcely stand the stress of awaiting the outcome. ''It's really emotional for me,'' said Ms. Hoffman, the manager of a clothing store. ''I'll listen to the Zogby poll, and I'll watch 'Hardball' on MSNBC, and I wonder, Am I really voting because of the facts or is it all biased opinion and smear campaigns?'' 
 Issues that can fade into slogans and abstractions at campaign headquarters remain vivid and complex in northeastern Ohio. A new Wal-Mart is hiring hundreds here, while manufacturers are shedding jobs as they relocate plants overseas or to states where unions are weak. Some soldiers are returning from Iraq as other reservists prepare to go.
 For the first time in their lives, Ms. Zeiger and Ms. Hoffman said, they attended a political protest on Friday, outside Mr. Bush's speech at the Palace Theater downtown. Ms. Zeiger said that her boyfriend's manufacturing job had been ''outsourced to India'' and that her own hours had been reduced because people were losing dental insurance.
 Of more than two dozen voters interviewed, several said the loss of manufacturing jobs began under President Bill Clinton, in what they called an inevitable economic transition. 
 Nancy Troyak, 55, said this campaign had exposed such raw feelings over economics that she could no longer talk politics with her eight elder siblings.
 ''They live in Pittsburgh, and they still have the blue-collar mentality that 'Someone took my job,''' said Ms. Troyak, a coal miner's daughter who has an M.B.A. and is a part-time instructor in business at Kent State University's Stark campus. She spoke while waiting to see Mr. Bush, standing with her ticket in a line 200 yards long. 
 She said of the election, ''This is the first one I've ever noticed that's dividing the family.''
 Some voters relish the intensity. Dennis and Carol Hickman have posted Bush-Cheney signs on their lawn. With a brash laugh, Mr. Hickman, 55, said he enjoyed teasing his father, a Kerry man.''He's very serious about it,'' Mr. Hickman said. ''I throw the anti-Kerry jokes just to get a reaction out of him.'' 
 But David G. Baker, a political scientist who is dean of Kent State's Stark campus, said he had noticed a marked drop in political discussion, at least between those who disagree.
 ''Because it is so divided, so closely divided and contested, and people feel so deeply, there actually isn't a whole lot of debate,'' Mr. Baker said in a telephone interview. ''I think people have learned you don't get in these pleasant, jocular exchanges. They get pretty nasty pretty fast, so they avoid it.''
 He said that in his subdivision of 52 houses, his neighbors had put out many signs for local candidates, but, apparently in hopes of avoiding argument, not a single sign for a presidential contender. 
 Stark County, which went narrowly for Mr. Bush in 2000, has voted for the winner in every election since 1962, save in 1976, when it supported Gerald Ford over Jimmy Carter. In a county poll at the end of September by the local newspaper, The Repository, Mr. Bush led, 46 percent to 44 percent. The margin of sampling error was four percentage points. 
 Like many others, David C. Kaminski, The Repository's editor, is looking forward to the end of the campaign, while wondering when that might occur. He is preparing his reporters to cover legal challenges to the vote. 
 Mr. Kaminski said that his staff was discouraged over the summer by an unaccustomed ''nasty tone'' in calls and letters from partisans. 
 Several voters said they hoped the politicking had helped the county's economy. But there are costs, too. At the farmers' market on Saturday, Mike Snider, 50, a bus mechanic who does not support either major candidate, said he was annoyed that 10 buses had been pulled out of service and used to block the streets outside Mr. Bush's event.
 Joseph Concatto, the chief of staff to the mayor, Janet Weir Creighton, a Republican, said the president's visit in July cost the city $18,000 in overtime wages. 
 Mr. Concatto added that, at a time the city is trying to build its job base, he was not happy to see Mr. Kerry advertising that Canton had lost jobs. ''I don't know that we want to be on the forefront because we're losing jobs,'' he said. 
 The people who seem the most jaded by all the political attention are the television reporters. On Cleveland's Fox Channel 8, the correspondent covering Mr. Bush observed that the candidates would be in Ohio ''again and again and again.''
 ''They should have mailboxes here, don't you think?'' he asked. 
 Over on NewsChannel 5, an anchor suggested, ''They should just get an apartment in the meantime and just stay here over the next two weeks.''


CORRECTION-DATE: November 1, 2004

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about the intense attention being focused this year on Stark County, a political bellwether in Ohio, misstated the starting year of its history of going the same way as the nation in every presidential election except one. The streak began in 1964, not 1962. (In 1976 the county went for Gerald Ford over Jimmy Carter.)

GRAPHIC: Photo: It was anti-Kerry signs versus anti-Bush signs on Friday in Canton, Ohio, with city buses blocking the street, when President Bush visited town for the second time in four months. (Photo by Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); US PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (90%); POLITICS (90%); POLITICAL ADVERTISING (90%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (90%); US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2008 (90%); ELECTIONS (89%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (79%); US REPUBLICAN PARTY (77%); POLITICAL PARTIES (74%); DISMISSALS (72%); AMERICAN FOOTBALL (70%); SPORTS (70%); MARKETING & ADVERTISING EXPENDITURE (66%); STADIUMS & ARENAS (65%); HIGH SCHOOL SPORTS (65%) Presidential Election of 2004; Political Advertising; Public Opinion; Geographic Profiles

PERSON: GEORGE W BUSH (93%); JOHN KERRY (79%); JOHN EDWARDS (78%) James Bennet; George W (Pres) Bush; John (Sen) Kerry

GEOGRAPHIC: CLEVELAND, OH, USA (92%) OHIO, USA (95%); VIRGINIA, USA (79%) UNITED STATES (95%) Canton (Ohio); Stark County (Ohio); Ohio

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 26, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section G; Column 1; Voter Guide 2004; THE BATTLEGROUND; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 1985 words

HEADLINE: Neck and Neck Around the Country

BYLINE: By ALAN GREENBLATT. 
Alan Greenblatt is a staff writer at Governing magazine.

 BODY:
The presidential campaign has been characterized as a battle in a few closely contested states, but this election also reveals how voters are polarized by region. The coasts are leaning toward John Kerry, while Southern, Plains and Rocky Mountain states are providing President Bush with his firmest support.
 The states that are closest are in those regions most in flux. Rapid population growth in the Sunbelt states of Florida and the Southwest has led to bifurcated political cultures in which newcomers are challenging the accepted order. Mr. Kerry is gaining strength in Rust Belt states leaking jobs -- most prominently in Michigan and normally Republican Ohio. And suburbanization in the Upper Midwest is putting generally Democratic states like Minnesota and Wisconsin within Mr. Bush's sights.
 The bulk of the most hotly contested local races are taking place in states that appear to favor Mr. Bush, including the races for governor in Indiana, Missouri and Montana and the Senate contests in Alaska, Oklahoma, South Dakota and both Carolinas. 
 In the presidential battleground states, as elsewhere, the race is dominated by a few key issues -- Iraq, terror, health care and the economy. Here is a look at 11 of the states that polls indicate are the most competitive.
 In addition, several states are bellwethers, among them New Jersey (included below). Mr. Kerry is still leading there, but if Mr. Bush carries the state, he will win more comfortably than he did four years ago. Similarly, if Mr. Kerry carries a state like Arkansas, which Mr. Bush won by 5 percentage points in 2000 and where he is ahead, Mr. Kerry is likely to be the next president. ALAN GREENBLATT

COLORADO
Registration has surged by about 10 percent this year in this fast-growing state and enrollment glitches have already caused concern. Conservative transplants from Southern California tilted Colorado firmly into the G.O.P. column, but the spike in Hispanic population -- Hispanics now represent nearly a fifth of the state's population -- has fueled Mr. Kerry's hopes, in conjunction with the Senate campaign of State Attorney General Ken Salazar. Running against Peter Coors, the beer magnate, Mr. Salazar has been polling better than Mr. Kerry among Hispanics and voters generally. A ballot initiative to divvy up the state's electoral votes based on the percentage of the popular vote has drawn national attention, but support for it appears to be slipping.

FLORIDA
Mr. Bush has helped engineer more than $10 billion worth of aid to hurricane victims. Mr. Bush's former housing director, Mel Martinez, a Republican, is running for Senate against Betty Castor for the seat being vacated by Bob Graham, a Democrat, helping to lift the president's numbers among voters of both Cuban and Puerto Rican heritage above 2000 levels. But Democrats retain a slight lead in voter registration. And health care concerns among the state's many elderly and low-income workers work against Mr. Bush. Mr. Kerry's supporters also remain energized by the disputed outcome in 2000. Ballot measures include something for everyone -- a proposed minimum wage increase with greater appeal for Democrats and, for conservatives, a cap on lawyers' fees and a parental notification requirement for minors seeking abortions.

IOWA
Mr. Bush has employed the powers of incumbency to try to break a deadlock here, holding a bill-signing ceremony in Des Moines on Oct. 4 to extend tax breaks. He also signed off on a disaster package that included $2.8 billion for farmers and ranchers. And on Oct. 15, his administration slapped a 15 percent duty on imported Canadian hogs. Still, in recent polls neither candidate holds a lead outside the margin of error. The economic picture is mixed and health care remains a prime concern of the elderly, who make up 15 percent of the population. People are nervous about conditions in Iraq, but some undecided voters remain unpersuaded of Mr. Kerry's leadership qualities in the war on terror. In 2002, Iowa was notable for many closely contested Congressional races, but the House races are less volatile this time, and Senator Charles E. Grassley, a Republican, is considered a shoo-in for a fifth term.

MICHIGAN
Mr. Kerry has not appeared here since mid-September and that fact, coupled with Mr. Bush's focus on terrorism, has helped tighten some polls in this state. Mr. Kerry has rested easier here than in the other big Midwestern battleground states and is still favored to win. The reason is that Michigan has been a leading job loser since Mr. Bush took office, shedding 15,000 payroll jobs in September alone. ''There's never been a day where the positive economic message nationally was not answered the next day by bad news in the state,'' said Ed Sarpolus, a pollster in Lansing. The Bush campaign is counting on a gay marriage amendment on the ballot to attract socially conservative voters, but its effect may be offset by gambling and education measures that are expected to increase turnout in heavily Democratic Detroit.

MINNESOTA
The debates helped shore up Mr. Kerry's support in this traditionally Democratic state, but the contest remains as close as any presidential election in recent memory. (Minnesota has gone Democratic in every presidential contest since 1972.) The Minneapolis-St. Paul area is growing faster than most other urban centers along the northern tier and many of the newcomers don't share the state's historic penchant for accepting high taxes in return for a high level of government service. Tim Pawlenty, the freshman Republican governor, has been hailed for closing a $4.6 billion deficit by cutting spending and not raising taxes. His home turf -- the increasingly Republican outer suburbs -- now accounts for a third of the statewide vote. Still, Democrats have been galvanized by opposition to the war in Iraq, which has consistently been greater here than nationwide.

NEVADA
In this gambling capital, they'll lay you a line on the election, but nobody's ready to bet serious money on the outcome. Nevada offers a test of the voting proclivities of two major demographic groups swelling the population in the nation's fastest-growing state. Hispanics tend to favor Democrats, but don't vote in proportion to their share of the population, while Anglo retirees from California and the Southwest do vote and are big fans of the state's low tax rates. Democrats have been edging ahead of Republicans in registration this year, but a judge blocked a Democratic attempt to keep the rolls open for citizens whose forms were said to have been destroyed by a Republican registration organization. Among the ballot measures this year is a proposed minimum-wage increase that Democrats hope will attract Hispanics.

NEW HAMPSHIRE
The state that gets early primary attention is receiving unaccustomed wooing at the campaign's end. This is the only Northeastern state Mr. Bush won in 2000 and he's struggling to win here again. Massachusetts transplants and commuters along the southern tier have mixed feelings about Mr. Kerry, dubious about some Republican charges against him but also hostile to tax increases. The state has a staunch antitax culture, so the G.O.P. message plays well. Veterans are also a major constituency. But concerns about health coverage in rural areas play to Mr. Kerry's advantage, as does a generally progressive tilt on social issues. Gov. Craig Benson, a Republican, is having a tough go of it in his first re-election bid against John Lynch, a business executive, in part because of scandals involving appointees and the former state attorney general.

NEW JERSEY
Voters across the country harbor concerns about progress in Iraq, but are uncomfortable with the notion of breaking faith with the president in wartime. That dynamic has put this normally Democratic state in play for Mr. Bush. New Jersey residents express high levels of anxiety about terrorist attacks. (About 700 state residents perished in the World Trade Center attack.) Democrats habitually win statewide races here and Al Gore carried the state by 16 points in 2000. Party officials were so confident that they sent staff members to help in other states. But the party has been weakened by Gov. James McGreevey's resignation announcement in August. Mr. Kerry maintains an edge in polls, although not a comfortable one. If he loses, it will be a sign that national security issues played well for Mr. Bush.

NEW MEXICO
If Mr. Kerry can't win this state, which Mr. Gore carried by just 366 votes in 2000, he will have a hard time winning the election. New Mexico provides a good mix of Democratic voters, including the nation's highest percentage of Hispanic residents (42 percent). A political committee led by Bill Richardson, the popular Democratic governor, has spent more than $800,000 in its efforts to register new voters, particularly Hispanics and American Indians. (The Democratic secretary of state turned back a Republican lawsuit seeking to require new registrants to show identification when voting.) Mr. Richardson is also a major voice for the Kerry campaign in local advertising. Rural voters are concerned about access to health care. Over all, registration favors the Democrats, if only barely, but Mr. Bush is aided by a fairly healthy economy (the state is an oil and natural gas producer) and by defense issues.

OHIO
The state has been a major job loser over the last three years, making the economy the race's major focus, but Iraq and security are concerns as well. Debates about policy, however, may be swamped by some of the country's loudest fights over voting procedures. Democrats and J. Kenneth Blackwell, the Republican secretary of state (and a state co-chairman of the Bush-Cheney campaign), have been engaging in court battles over provisional voting. (A federal judge sided with Democrats, but Mr. Blackwell won on appeal on Oct. 23.) Republicans have complained about voter fraud, including allegations that a man was paid with crack cocaine to sign up fictitious voters. Tax increase proposals and scandals involving state Republican officials have hurt the Republican cause here, but a gay marriage ban on the ballot should help turn out conservatives.

PENNSYLVANIA
Mirroring the nation as a whole, this state has populous, heavily Democratic areas to the east and west (Philadelphia and Pittsburgh) that bound larger expanses of heavily Republican territory. With those areas canceling each other out, the battle will be won in the Philadelphia suburbs. They tend to vote Republican, but are progressive on issues like abortion, the environment and gun control. (Contentious Congressional races in the southwest corner of the state will promote local turnout.) Huge battles are erupting at the county level over voting issues, including registration, identification and polling place disputes. Some counties have mailed absentee ballots listing Ralph Nader, an independent presidential candidate, before the United States Supreme Court rejected his case seeking a place on the state's ballot.

WISCONSIN
The state had been leaning toward Mr. Bush, but regular Democratic voters appear to have come home to Mr. Kerry since the presidential debates. The state has a dovish tradition on defense issues and Iraq is an unpopular cause with many voters. But suburban residents between Green Bay and the Illinois border are pleased with the low unemployment rate and are leaning more Republican. Loss of manufacturing jobs has hurt Mr. Bush, and the debate over importing prescription drugs from Canada -- a major issue for Mr. Kerry -- has gathered a lot of attention. Mr. Bush took credit for supporting a federal dairy price support program at an Oct. 7 appearance in Wausau, but Congressional Republicans excised the measure the next day. Sen. Russell D. Feingold, a Democrat seeking a third term, has sought to make an issue of the soon-to-expire dairy program.

PUB-DATE: October 26, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section C; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk; Economy Improves, but Not Optimism; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1724 words

HEADLINE: In Pennsylvania, a Swing State, Few Feel Flush

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: YORK, Pa., Oct 23 

 BODY:
It has become much easier to find a job here in the last year, but few people are feeling flush.
 George Firestone, who locates underground cables for telephone repair crews, recently learned that he would not be getting the $1.50-an-hour wage increase he had been expecting. His wife, Nicole, has $4,000 in bills after lung surgery last year, even though they both are covered by health insurance.
 ''We've pretty much abandoned our plans to buy a house,'' Ms. Firestone said as the couple ushered their three children into a Wal-Mart store here in this classic midsize American city with a mix of basic industries and white-collar services. ''Prices for groceries and gasoline are going up every week. We're paying about $40 a week for gasoline.'' 
 With the presidential election looming on Nov. 2, economic growth and hiring continue to march forward. But soaring oil prices and a persistently weak job market have made the recovery more fragile and sluggish than it seemed just a few months ago.
 Middle-income consumers, who kept buying houses and cars through the downturn, are now feeling squeezed between higher prices and stagnant wages. Because much of their recent spending was financed with borrowed money rather than higher incomes, many are either feeling tapped out or simply ready for a pause.
 ''We just finished a big addition, and we bought a lot of furniture to put in it,'' said Tracy Wagner, a stay-at-home mother whose husband works as a mechanical engineer. ''Unless we move, we won't need to spend as much this year.''
 President Bush and Senator John Kerry trade dueling economic outlooks almost every day. Mr. Bush boasts that the nation has added 1.8 million jobs in the last year and that tax cuts have helped the economy rebound. Mr. Kerry points out that real household incomes and employment have both declined since Mr. Bush took office while the number of people in poverty is up.
 Both candidates are right, up to a point. Analysts estimate that the economy is growing at a relatively robust annual pace of about 4 percent, above its average trend rate. And there is no doubt that lots of Americans are in many ways enjoying more creature comforts than ever before.
 Thanks to the Federal Reserve's decision to cut interest rates sharply, to their lowest level since 1958, the rate of homeownership has climbed to a record 69 percent. Americans, on average, live in bigger houses, drive bigger vehicles, surf the Internet with faster connections and talk on cellphones more than they did four years ago.
 But a long list of economic indicators suggests that many Americans are poorer today than they were when Mr. Bush took office.
 Median household income and median household wealth, adjusted for inflation, are still slightly lower than they were four years ago. Consumer debt, meanwhile, has soared to new records.
 Monthly debt payments, as a share of take-home pay, are just below the record levels set earlier this year. Mortgage foreclosure rates and write-offs for bad credit card debt are also near record levels, despite extraordinarily low interest rates.
 ''Most American households are financially worse off today than they were four years ago,'' said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com, a research firm based in the Philadelphia suburb of West Chester. Median household incomes and median household wealth, he said, were hit hard by the weak job market, high energy prices and the explosion of mortgage debt.
 ''The fruits of the economic recovery have largely accrued to upper-income households,'' Mr. Zandi said. ''Those are the one who benefited from the surge in house prices. They also enjoyed rising investment income and it is their part of the job market that has been strongest.''
 That poses a difficult challenge for whoever wins the presidential election. With oil prices surging to $55 a barrel from $30 last summer, economists have already reduced their forecasts for economic growth, and sustained high prices could lead to more painful jolts.
 Mr. Bush was able to soften the last downturn by pushing through tax cuts totaling $1.9 trillion over 10 years. But with the federal budget deficit hitting $415 billion this year, and foreign investors increasingly jittery about America's debt to the rest of the world, the next president will have little ability to cut taxes even more.
 Nor can the next president expect much help from the Federal Reserve, which fueled consumer spending by cutting interest rates 13 times from early 2001 to June 2003. Worried about provoking a new round of inflation, the Fed is now increasing rates gradually and is expected to keep raising them for at least the next year.
 The combined impact of tax cuts and cheap money has contributed to what Ethan Harris, chief economist at Lehman Brothers, called the ''supersizing'' of American lifestyles.
 ''Rising living standards are not a new phenomenon,'' Mr. Harris noted. ''What's different about this period is that the rise in spending is being financed by lower savings and higher borrowing.''
 Most economists believe that the economy expanded at an annual rate of more than 4 percent in the third quarter of 2004 (the Commerce Department is scheduled to report the data on Friday) and that growth will average about 3.5 percent next year.
 But surging oil prices have created new uncertainty, raising questions about whether business investment will pick up the slack as consumer spending grows more slowly.
 Despite Mr. Bush's repeated declaration that the economy is strong and getting stronger, consumer confidence has plunged in the last few months. The University of Michigan's monthly survey of consumers showed an unexpectedly sharp drop this month, according to preliminary estimates, and the Conference Board is expected to show a similar drop in its survey.
 ''Absent a sudden, strong reacceleration in employment growth, we think it is therefore just a matter of time before spending growth slows further,'' warned Ian Shepherdson of High-Frequency Economics, an independent investment analyst based in Valhalla, N.Y. ''The risk of a seriously soft holiday season is growing by the day.'' 
 Allen Sinai of Decision Economics, a forecasting firm, said, ''The corporations I'm talking to had a pretty good year.'' 
 But ''corporate America is still sitting on tons of cash,'' he said. ''I've never seen a more risk-averse bunch of executives than the ones I've been talking to.''
 Federal Reserve officials are watching the potential impact of oil prices with growing apprehension, generally estimating that the rising costs of imported oil have already amounted to a $75 billion tax on the economy.
 ''I don't mean to conjure up the grim days of the 1970's, when oil price shocks hit the economy very hard,'' said Janet Yellen, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, in a speech last week. ''But what adds to concerns about the higher oil prices is the possibility that they might continue, or even worsen, cutting further into people's and firms' ability to spend.''
 The fragility of the recovery is apparent here in Pennsylvania, a political swing state that has lost tens of thousands of manufacturing jobs over the last four years. Job creation has picked up noticeably over the last year, with statewide employment climbing by 147,000 jobs in the 12 months through September.
 But that still leaves the state with 71,200 fewer jobs than it had in March 2001, when the recession officially began, and the adult population has climbed during that period.
 In York, an area with manufacturing and service companies, the unemployment rate is comparatively low at 4.4 percent and even a few factories have begun to rehire workers. ''We could find jobs for 400 people right now,'' said Michael Smeltzer, director of the Manufacturers' Association of South Central Pennsylvania. ''That is a huge shift from a year ago.''
 But the picture in the state is mixed. Several big employers have closed all or part of their operations in the last several months. Glatfelter, a long-time producer of specialty paper products, is eliminating about 100 jobs at its paper mill in Spring Grove. 
 Breuners Home Furnishings, based in Lancaster and one of the nation's biggest furniture retailers, is expected to close most of its 47 stores nationwide. Because Breuners owned numerous stores in Pennsylvania, its demise should have helped lift sales at local rivals.
 But Wolf Furniture, a family-owned chain with eight stores in the area, said it was simply keeping on track with sales from last year.
 Mr. Smeltzer, at the manufacturing association, said executives were still nervous about the future, particularly given the uncertainty about oil prices.
 ''The jury is still out on whether this economic recovery is sustainable,'' Mr. Smeltzer said.
 That could be an ominous sign. For the last several years, most economists have been expecting a ''hand off'' from consumers to corporations as the main engine of growth. The theory has been that tax cuts and low interest rates propped up consumer spending through the downturn, and that business investment would pick up as the global economy improved.
 Business spending did indeed revive over the last year, after plunging in response to the stock market fall and the economic downturn. But business investment still remains comparatively modest, even though profits have climbed by more than 30 percent over the last year.
 The Conference Board, which surveys chief executives once every quarter, found that business confidence dropped noticeably in the summer as well as in the fall.
 If business investment continues to lag, the big question is how much energy America's consumers have left in them.
 Mr. Harris of Lehman Brothers predicts that consumers will continue to keep spending to maintain the lifestyles to which they have become accustomed. But people like Tracy and Jeff Wagner do not fit that pattern.
 Mr. Wagner, a mechanical engineer, accepted a lower-paying job when his previous employer decided to cut back. The family stayed in their two-bedroom house, then took advantage of low interest rates to reduce their mortgage and take out a home-equity loan to pay for a new addition.
 Tracy Wagner expressed little desire to make new purchases. As for her husband, she added, ''I don't think he is expecting his income to go up anytime soon.''
